name: Kepler-452b
description: Kepler-452b, often called 'Earth's cousin,' orbits a G-type star similar to the Sun. Discovered by the Kepler mission, it resides in the habitable zone, where liquid water could exist. Its size and orbit make it a prime candidate in the search for life.

name: HD 189733 b
description: HD 189733 b is a gas giant with extreme weather, including supersonic winds and possible glass rain. Its atmosphere has hydrogen cyanide, giving it a striking blue hue. Discovered via the transit method, it offers insights into exoplanetary atmospheres.

name: WASP-127 b
description: WASP-127 b is an ultra-low-density gas giant with an extended atmosphere rich in water vapor. Its discovery provides new insights into the structure and composition of exoplanetary atmospheres.

name: TrES-2b
description: TrES-2b is one of the darkest known exoplanets, reflecting less than 1% of the light that hits it. Its dark color is likely due to light-absorbing chemicals in its atmosphere. It orbits very close to its star and was discovered by the transit method.

name: Proxima Centauri b
description: Proxima Centauri b is the closest known exoplanet to Earth, orbiting the red dwarf Proxima Centauri. It lies within the star's habitable zone, making it a candidate for liquid water, though stellar flares may impact its habitability.

name: Kepler-22b
description: Kepler-22b is an exoplanet located in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. Its size suggests it could be a rocky world or a water-rich planet. Discovered in 2011, it marked one of the first potentially habitable exoplanets found by Kepler.

name: GJ 1214 b
description: GJ 1214 b is a water-rich 'mini-Neptune' with a thick atmosphere of hydrogen and helium. Its close orbit to its star results in high temperatures, and it is one of the best-studied exoplanets for atmospheric research.

name: Kepler-10b
description: Kepler-10b was the first confirmed rocky exoplanet discovered by Kepler. Extremely close to its star, it experiences scorching temperatures and may have a lava-covered surface, providing insights into planet formation in extreme environments.

name: HD 209458 b
description: HD 209458 b, also known as Osiris, is a hot Jupiter famous for being the first exoplanet with an observed atmosphere. Hydrogen, oxygen, and carbon have been detected, making it a benchmark for atmospheric studies.

name: 51 Pegasi b
description: 51 Pegasi b was the first exoplanet discovered around a Sun-like star. Its discovery in 1995 confirmed that planets exist outside our solar system, revolutionizing astronomy. It orbits extremely close to its host star.

name: Kepler-62f
description: Kepler-62f is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a K-type star. It may have liquid water on its surface, and its orbit allows for potentially stable climates, making it one of the most promising candidates for habitability beyond Earth.

name: Kepler-69c
description: Kepler-69c orbits within the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. Its size suggests a rocky composition, and its discovery via the transit method highlights the ability of Kepler to detect Earth-like exoplanets.

name: HD 97658 b
description: HD 97658 b is a super-Earth with a thick atmosphere, possibly dominated by hydrogen and helium. It was discovered via radial velocity and is a key target for atmospheric characterization using space telescopes.

name: GJ 436 b
description: GJ 436 b is a hot Neptune with a gaseous envelope and a possible water-rich core. Its atmosphere contains hydrogen and helium, and it has been extensively studied using transit spectroscopy.

name: Kepler-438b
description: Kepler-438b is an Earth-size exoplanet in the habitable zone of its star. It is considered one of the most Earth-like planets known, with a rocky composition and potential for liquid water, although stellar activity may affect habitability.

name: Kepler-440b
description: Kepler-440b is a super-Earth orbiting in the habitable zone of a K-type star. Its moderate size and distance from its star make it a strong candidate for supporting temperate conditions and possibly liquid water.

name: LHS 1140 b
description: LHS 1140 b is a dense super-Earth orbiting a red dwarf star. Its rocky composition and location in the habitable zone make it a prime candidate for follow-up studies on atmospheric and surface conditions.

name: Kepler-442b
description: Kepler-442b is a rocky super-Earth in the habitable zone of a K-type star. Its discovery via transit photometry revealed its potential for temperate conditions and possible water retention, making it a focus for habitability studies.

name: HD 40307 g
description: HD 40307 g orbits within the habitable zone of a K2.5V star. Its mass suggests a rocky or water-rich composition, and it was discovered using radial velocity measurements. It is considered a candidate for hosting life.

name: Kepler-186f
description: Kepler-186f is the first Earth-sized planet discovered in the habitable zone of another star. Its potential for liquid water makes it an important object in the search for extraterrestrial life. It orbits an M-dwarf star.

name: TRAPPIST-1d
description: TRAPPIST-1d is a rocky planet in the TRAPPIST-1 system, located in the habitable zone. It is part of a seven-planet system around an ultra-cool red dwarf and is considered a key target for studies of potential habitability.

name: TRAPPIST-1e
description: TRAPPIST-1e is similar in size to Earth and resides in the habitable zone. Its moderate size, rocky composition, and relatively temperate orbit make it one of the most promising planets for the presence of liquid water.

name: TRAPPIST-1f
description: TRAPPIST-1f orbits a dim red dwarf star and lies within the outer edge of the habitable zone. Its rocky nature and potential for water make it a focus for future observational studies.

name: TRAPPIST-1g
description: TRAPPIST-1g is one of the outer planets in the TRAPPIST-1 system. Its rocky surface and position within the habitable zone make it a key target for atmospheric and habitability studies.

name: TRAPPIST-1h
description: TRAPPIST-1h is the outermost planet of its system. Likely rocky and very cold, it receives minimal starlight, but it is important for understanding the formation and evolution of compact planetary systems.

name: Kepler-37b
description: Kepler-37b is one of the smallest exoplanets discovered, slightly larger than our Moon. It orbits very close to its star, making it extremely hot and inhospitable.

name: Kepler-37c
description: Kepler-37c is larger than Kepler-37b but still smaller than Earth. It orbits close to its star, likely resulting in a rocky surface with high temperatures.

name: Kepler-37d
description: Kepler-37d is a mini-Neptune with a thick gaseous envelope. Its size and density suggest a small rocky core surrounded by an atmosphere of hydrogen and helium.

name: Kepler-62e
description: Kepler-62e is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a K-type star. Its orbit and size make it a strong candidate for liquid water and a temperate climate.

name: HD 219134 b
description: HD 219134 b is a rocky exoplanet orbiting a K-type star. Its density and size suggest a solid surface, and its proximity to its star results in high surface temperatures.

name: HD 219134 c
description: HD 219134 c is a rocky super-Earth with a dense composition. Orbiting close to its star, it experiences high surface temperatures, making it uninhabitable but ideal for studying rocky exoplanet structure.

name: HD 219134 d
description: HD 219134 d is a mini-Neptune with a gaseous envelope surrounding a rocky core. Its moderate distance from its star allows for studies of planetary atmospheres under mild stellar irradiation.

name: 55 Cancri e
description: 55 Cancri e is an ultra-hot super-Earth with extreme surface temperatures, possibly featuring molten rock. Its close orbit around a G-type star makes it a prime target for studies of tidal heating and atmospheric dynamics.

name: 55 Cancri f
description: 55 Cancri f is a gas giant orbiting near the outer habitable zone of its star. Its size and composition resemble that of Saturn, making it valuable for comparative planetology with Solar System giants.

name: 55 Cancri b
description: 55 Cancri b is a Jupiter-like planet with a short orbital period. Its proximity to the star causes high irradiation, affecting atmospheric dynamics and potentially stripping lighter elements over time.

name: HD 106906 b
description: HD 106906 b is a massive gas giant orbiting extremely far from its host star. Its wide orbit challenges planet formation theories and provides a unique laboratory for studying young planetary atmospheres.

name: HR 8799 c
description: HR 8799 c is a directly imaged gas giant with a wide orbit. Its atmospheric studies reveal water vapor, carbon monoxide, and methane, providing critical insights into young giant planet formation.

name: HR 8799 d
description: HR 8799 d is another directly imaged gas giant in a multi-planet system. Its wide orbit and youth allow scientists to study atmospheric evolution in early planetary systems.

name: HR 8799 e
description: HR 8799 e orbits close to its star compared to its siblings, yet remains a young gas giant. Its dynamic environment allows for studies of gravitational interactions in multi-planet systems.

name: Kepler-167e
description: Kepler-167e is a gas giant with a long orbital period around a Sun-like star. Its discovery via transit timing variations allows astronomers to constrain its mass and orbit precisely.

name: Gliese 667 Cc
description: Gliese 667 Cc is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a red dwarf. Its moderate mass and distance make it one of the most promising exoplanets for potential liquid water.

name: Gliese 667 Cd
description: Gliese 667 Cd orbits just outside the habitable zone. Likely rocky, its composition and orbital dynamics provide insight into planet formation around low-mass stars.

name: Gliese 581 c
description: Gliese 581 c was one of the first potentially habitable exoplanets discovered. Its proximity to its star may induce a tidally locked rotation, affecting climate patterns.

name: Gliese 581 d
description: Gliese 581 d is near the outer edge of the habitable zone. Its larger mass and rocky composition suggest a strong gravitational hold on a dense atmosphere, which could retain heat.

name: Gliese 581 e
description: Gliese 581 e is the innermost planet of its system, likely rocky but too close to its star to be habitable. Its discovery helps astronomers understand compact planetary system architectures.

name: Kepler-289c
description: Kepler-289c is a gas giant in a multi-planet system. Its gravitational influence affects neighboring planets, making it important for studying planetary dynamics.

name: Kepler-289b
description: Kepler-289b is a rocky super-Earth closer to its star, providing a contrast to its gas giant sibling. Its discovery via transit methods highlights the diversity of planetary systems.

name: Kepler-90 h
description: Kepler-90 h is the outermost planet of the eight known planets in the Kepler-90 system, a system with a similar architecture to our Solar System. Its discovery confirmed the complexity of exoplanetary systems.

name: Kepler-90 g
description: Kepler-90 g is a gas giant in a compact planetary system. Its proximity to the star relative to its size allows studies of planet-star interactions and migration histories.

name: Kepler-90 f
description: Kepler-90 f orbits closer than its outer siblings and experiences intense stellar radiation. It provides a laboratory for studying atmospheric escape and composition in gas giants.

name: HD 95086 b
description: HD 95086 b is a young gas giant imaged directly, orbiting far from its host star. Its massive size and wide orbit provide clues to planet formation in the outer regions of planetary systems.

name: Kepler-20e
description: Kepler-20e is a rocky exoplanet smaller than Earth, orbiting very close to its star. Its extreme proximity results in scorching surface temperatures, providing insights into the dynamics of tightly-packed planetary systems.

name: Kepler-20f
description: Kepler-20f is slightly larger than Earth and resides near the inner edge of its star's habitable zone. Its rocky composition and orbit make it ideal for studying exoplanet diversity.

name: Kepler-20c
description: Kepler-20c is a mini-Neptune with a gaseous envelope over a rocky core. Its proximity to the host star allows astronomers to study atmospheric loss and irradiation effects.

name: Kepler-20d
description: Kepler-20d orbits farther out than its sibling planets, providing a unique contrast for studying composition gradients in compact planetary systems.

name: HD 189733 c
description: HD 189733 c is a hypothetical gas giant farther out in the system than the well-known HD 189733 b. Its presence has been suggested through long-term radial velocity trends and offers a case study in multi-planet system dynamics.

name: Kepler-11 f
description: Kepler-11 f is a mini-Neptune in a tightly-packed six-planet system. Its gaseous envelope over a small core provides important insights into planet formation in dense planetary systems.

name: Kepler-11 e
description: Kepler-11 e is one of the larger planets in its compact system. Its low density suggests a significant hydrogen-helium atmosphere, making it an excellent candidate for studying atmospheric retention in closely-orbiting planets.

name: Kepler-11 d
description: Kepler-11 d orbits closer to its star than e and f, allowing comparisons of atmospheric loss and planetary composition across different distances in the same system.

name: Kepler-11 c
description: Kepler-11 c is a dense super-Earth with a rocky composition, orbiting very close to its star. Its presence in a tightly-packed multi-planet system helps astronomers study orbital resonances and system stability.

name: WASP-12b
description: WASP-12b is an ultra-hot Jupiter, tidally distorted by its star. Its atmosphere is overflowing onto the star, providing a unique case for studying extreme star-planet interactions.

name: WASP-17b
description: WASP-17b is a highly inflated gas giant with a retrograde orbit. Its low density and large radius make it one of the puffiest known exoplanets, ideal for atmospheric studies.

name: CoRoT-7b
description: CoRoT-7b is a rocky super-Earth with a likely molten surface due to extreme proximity to its star. Its discovery demonstrated the capability of transit surveys to detect small, dense exoplanets.

name: CoRoT-7c
description: CoRoT-7c is a slightly larger sibling to CoRoT-7b, orbiting further out. Its mass and radius indicate a rocky composition, offering comparative insights into planets in extremely close orbits.

name: HAT-P-11b
description: HAT-P-11b is a Neptune-sized planet with a gaseous envelope and strong atmospheric features. Its transits have allowed detailed studies of its atmosphere and possible cloud patterns.

name: HAT-P-7b
description: HAT-P-7b is a highly irradiated hot Jupiter, known for its extreme day-night temperature contrast. Observations of its orbit and atmosphere help study tidal forces and atmospheric dynamics.

name: Kepler-36b
description: Kepler-36b is a dense super-Earth in a system with two closely spaced planets, leading to gravitational interactions. Its contrasting density with Kepler-36c provides insights into planetary composition diversity.

name: Kepler-36c
description: Kepler-36c is a low-density mini-Neptune close to its super-Earth sibling. The system is a benchmark for studying planetary formation and migration in compact orbits.

name: Kepler-62d
description: Kepler-62d is part of a five-planet system, orbiting slightly interior to the habitable zone. Its size and rocky composition provide a contrast to its more temperate siblings.

name: Kepler-62c
description: Kepler-62c is a mini-Neptune closer to its star, with a gaseous envelope over a solid core. Its orbital arrangement within a multi-planet system allows study of planet migration and system stability.

name: GJ 1214 b
description: GJ 1214 b is a well-studied mini-Neptune orbiting a red dwarf. Its thick atmosphere may contain water vapor, making it a prime target for atmospheric characterization with upcoming telescopes.

name: GJ 436 b
description: GJ 436 b is a Neptune-sized planet with a bloated atmosphere and extreme temperatures. It shows evidence of atmospheric escape, offering clues to planetary evolution around red dwarfs.

name: Tau Ceti e
description: Tau Ceti e orbits a Sun-like star within the inner edge of its habitable zone. Its mass and orbital distance make it an intriguing candidate for climate modeling and potential habitability studies.

name: Tau Ceti f
description: Tau Ceti f lies near the outer habitable zone. Its slightly larger mass than e may help retain an atmosphere capable of supporting moderate temperatures under favorable conditions.

name: HD 40307 g
description: HD 40307 g is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a K-type star. Its orbital period and mass suggest a rocky composition, and it is a focus for exoplanet habitability studies.

name: HD 40307 f
description: HD 40307 f is slightly closer to the star than g, orbiting within a warmer region. Its rocky nature makes it ideal for comparative studies with its sibling planet HD 40307 g.

name: Kepler-22b
description: Kepler-22b was the first confirmed planet in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. Its size suggests a mix of rocky and gaseous components, making it key for studying super-Earth atmospheres.

name: Kepler-186f
description: Kepler-186f is the first Earth-sized planet discovered in the habitable zone of its star. Its potential for liquid water makes it one of the most famous exoplanets for habitability studies.

name: Kepler-62b
description: Kepler-62b is the innermost planet of its system, with a rocky composition and extreme temperatures. It helps astronomers understand orbital dynamics and formation in multi-planet systems.

name: Kepler-62a
description: Kepler-62a is a mini-Neptune in a compact planetary system. Its gaseous envelope and close orbit provide insight into planet migration and atmospheric retention under intense stellar radiation.

name: HD 85512 b
description: HD 85512 b is a super-Earth orbiting a K-type star in the inner edge of its habitable zone. Its size and location make it an important candidate for studies of potential habitability and atmosphere retention.

name: HD 40307 b
description: HD 40307 b is a dense super-Earth close to its host star. Its tight orbit and rocky composition provide insight into planet formation around K-type stars.

name: HD 40307 c
description: HD 40307 c is slightly farther from its star than HD 40307 b. Its orbit and mass make it an important comparison for studying planetary composition and potential atmospheres in compact systems.

name: HD 219134 b
description: HD 219134 b is a rocky super-Earth orbiting a K-type star. Its close orbit and size make it a benchmark for studying rocky planet densities and compositions in nearby systems.

name: HD 219134 f
description: HD 219134 f is a mini-Neptune with a thin gaseous envelope over a rocky core. Its discovery and mass measurements help astronomers understand planet diversity in multi-planet systems.

name: HD 219134 g
description: HD 219134 g is a distant gas giant in the system, offering insights into the formation of outer giant planets in compact multi-planet systems.

name: Kapteyn b
description: Kapteyn b is an ancient super-Earth orbiting a nearby red sub-dwarf. Its age and location make it a rare laboratory for studying long-term planetary evolution.

name: Kapteyn c
description: Kapteyn c is a larger sibling to Kapteyn b, orbiting further out. Its long orbital period and rocky nature provide comparative insights into planet formation around old stars.

name: OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb
description: OGLE-2005-BLG-390Lb is a cold super-Earth discovered via microlensing. Its large distance from a faint star makes it one of the coldest known exoplanets, valuable for studies of planet formation in low-luminosity systems.

name: OGLE-2016-BLG-1195Lb
description: OGLE-2016-BLG-1195Lb is an Earth-mass exoplanet discovered by microlensing. Its location and size make it one of the few known potentially rocky planets in distant Galactic regions.

name: 55 Cancri e
description: 55 Cancri e is a lava world, extremely close to its star, with surface temperatures high enough to melt rock. Its study helps understand planetary compositions under extreme irradiation.

name: 55 Cancri b
description: 55 Cancri b is a gas giant in a multi-planet system. Its gravitational influence shapes the orbits of nearby planets, providing key insights into planetary dynamics.

name: 55 Cancri c
description: 55 Cancri c is a massive gas giant orbiting its star every 44 days. Its density and orbital configuration help study the effects of planetary migration in compact systems.

name: 55 Cancri f
description: 55 Cancri f is located in the outer part of its star system, offering clues about long-range planet formation and potential habitability of outer system moons.

name: HD 189733 b
description: HD 189733 b is a hot Jupiter with high-speed winds and extreme weather patterns. Its blue color is due to silicate particles in its atmosphere, making it one of the most studied exoplanets.

name: HD 189733 c
description: HD 189733 c is a gas giant orbiting further out in the system. It offers comparative studies for its inner hot Jupiter sibling and insights into planetary atmospheric dynamics.

name: GJ 876 b
description: GJ 876 b is a Jupiter-like planet in resonance with other planets in its system. Its interactions are key to understanding orbital resonances and multi-planet system dynamics.

name: GJ 876 c
description: GJ 876 c is a gas giant in close resonance with GJ 876 b. Its orbit and mass allow scientists to study strong gravitational interactions and long-term system stability.

name: GJ 876 d
description: GJ 876 d is the innermost planet in the system, a rocky super-Earth extremely close to its red dwarf star. Its tight orbit helps study tidal effects and planet-star interactions.

name: OGLE-2006-BLG-109Lb
description: OGLE-2006-BLG-109Lb is a gas giant discovered via microlensing. Its position and mass provide insight into cold gas giant formation and the frequency of Jupiter analogs in our galaxy.

name: Kepler-452b
description: Kepler-452b is an Earth-sized super-Earth orbiting a Sun-like star in the habitable zone. Its discovery highlights potential Earth analogs and long-term planetary climate stability.

name: Kepler-1606b
description: Kepler-1606b is a mini-Neptune orbiting close to its star. Its low density suggests a thick hydrogen-helium atmosphere, providing a window into atmospheric retention under strong stellar irradiation.

name: Kepler-1606c
description: Kepler-1606c is a rocky super-Earth slightly farther from its star than Kepler-1606b. Its composition and orbital arrangement allow studies of close-orbit planetary system architectures.

name: Kepler-444f
description: Kepler-444f orbits an ancient star system over 11 billion years old. Its age makes it a unique laboratory for studying planetary formation and survival over cosmic timescales.

name: Kepler-444e
description: Kepler-444e is another rocky planet in the ancient Kepler-444 system. Its close orbit contributes to the compact multi-planet arrangement, offering clues about early planetary system formation.

name: HD 97658 b
description: HD 97658 b is a dense super-Earth with a rocky core and possible thin atmosphere. Its proximity to a bright K-type star allows precise radial velocity and transit measurements.

name: HD 219134 h
description: HD 219134 h is a distant gas giant, orbiting far from its star. Its mass and position provide comparative studies with inner super-Earths in the same system.

name: Kepler-289d
description: Kepler-289d is a mini-Neptune with a low-density gaseous envelope. Its orbital spacing within a multi-planet system offers insights into resonant chains and planetary migration.

name: Kepler-289c
description: Kepler-289c is a rocky super-Earth in the same system as Kepler-289d. Its density and orbital configuration help understand interactions between super-Earths and mini-Neptunes.

name: Kepler-289b
description: Kepler-289b is the innermost rocky planet of its system. Its close orbit provides a benchmark for studying tidal interactions and planet formation in tightly packed systems.

name: Kepler-20e
description: Kepler-20e is an Earth-sized rocky planet in a compact multi-planet system. Its proximity to the star results in high surface temperatures, offering insight into the formation of tightly packed inner planets.

name: Kepler-20f
description: Kepler-20f is slightly larger than Earth and orbits farther out than Kepler-20e. Its size and orbit help study variations in planetary compositions within the same system.

name: Kepler-18b
description: Kepler-18b is a dense super-Earth with a rocky core and possible thin atmosphere. Its short orbital period allows repeated transits, facilitating precise density and composition measurements.

name: Kepler-18c
description: Kepler-18c is a mini-Neptune with a gaseous envelope over a rocky core. Its orbital interactions with other planets in the system provide insights into planetary migration and resonance.

name: Kepler-18d
description: Kepler-18d orbits farther from the star than its siblings. Its presence in the system helps astronomers study the diversity of mini-Neptunes in compact multi-planet systems.

name: Gliese 667 Cc
description: Gliese 667 Cc is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a red dwarf. Its position and mass make it a prime candidate for studying potential habitability and atmospheric retention around low-mass stars.

name: Gliese 667 Cf
description: Gliese 667 Cf orbits farther from its star than Cc, lying near the outer habitable zone. Its mass and orbit provide insight into climate modeling and long-term stability of planets around red dwarfs.

name: Gliese 436 b
description: Gliese 436 b is a Neptune-sized planet with a gaseous envelope. It exhibits extreme temperatures and atmospheric escape, making it an ideal candidate for studying planetary evaporation processes.

name: Gliese 581 g
description: Gliese 581 g is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a red dwarf. Its potential for liquid water makes it one of the most notable candidates for habitability studies.

name: Gliese 581 d
description: Gliese 581 d orbits near the outer edge of the habitable zone. Its size and orbit provide a contrast to Gliese 581 g, helping to study potential habitability in multiple-planet systems.

name: Proxima Centauri b
description: Proxima Centauri b is a rocky planet in the habitable zone of the closest star to the Sun. Its potential for liquid water and proximity make it a prime target for atmospheric characterization.

name: Proxima Centauri c
description: Proxima Centauri c is a super-Earth orbiting farther out from its host star. Its longer orbital period and mass provide valuable insights into outer planetary system dynamics.

name: Wolf 1061 c
description: Wolf 1061 c is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a nearby red dwarf. Its discovery has fueled interest in nearby potentially habitable exoplanets.

name: Wolf 1061 b
description: Wolf 1061 b is the innermost planet in the system, a rocky world with high surface temperatures. Its proximity to the star offers insights into tidal locking and atmospheric loss.

name: Wolf 1061 d
description: Wolf 1061 d is the outermost planet of the system. Its orbit near the edge of the habitable zone allows studies of climate modeling under varying stellar flux.

name: Luyten b
description: Luyten b is a rocky super-Earth in the habitable zone of a nearby red dwarf. Its orbit and mass make it a candidate for atmospheric studies and habitability potential.

name: Ross 128 b
description: Ross 128 b is a nearby Earth-sized planet orbiting a quiet red dwarf. Its temperate orbit and proximity make it ideal for studying exoplanet climates and stellar influence on habitability.

name: Tau Ceti g
description: Tau Ceti g orbits at the outer edge of the habitable zone, with a mass suggesting a rocky composition. It provides comparative data alongside other Tau Ceti planets.

name: Kapteyn d
description: Kapteyn d is a super-Earth located further out than its siblings. Its orbit and age offer unique insights into planetary evolution in ancient systems.

name: HD 20794 c
description: HD 20794 c is a super-Earth orbiting a Sun-like star. Its size, mass, and orbit make it valuable for studies of rocky planet formation and potential habitability.

name: HD 40307 g
description: HD 40307 g is a super-Earth orbiting within the habitable zone of its K-type star. Its orbit and mass make it a prime candidate for studying potential atmospheres on exoplanets.

name: HD 40307 d
description: HD 40307 d is one of the inner super-Earths in its system. Its density and orbital configuration provide insights into formation mechanisms of compact planetary systems.

name: HD 40307 e
description: HD 40307 e orbits between planets d and f, creating dynamic interactions within the system. Its properties help study orbital resonances in multi-planet systems.

name: HD 97658 c
description: HD 97658 c is a super-Earth orbiting a K-type star. Its characteristics allow for comparative studies alongside HD 97658 b in terms of density, composition, and orbital dynamics.

name: HD 97658 d
description: HD 97658 d is a mini-Neptune with a significant gaseous envelope. Its study provides insights into the formation and retention of atmospheres in close-in planets.

name: Gliese 667 Ce
description: Gliese 667 Ce is a super-Earth orbiting in the habitable zone of a red dwarf. Its mass and position make it a notable target for studies on potential habitability.

name: Gliese 667 Cd
description: Gliese 667 Cd orbits near the outer habitable zone of its star. Its orbit and composition provide valuable information on climate and atmospheric retention in red dwarf systems.

name: GJ 667 Cb
description: GJ 667 Cb is a close-orbiting super-Earth with high surface temperatures. Its proximity to the host star allows for studies of tidal effects and stellar interactions.

name: Kepler-22b
description: Kepler-22b is a super-Earth in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star. Its discovery marked one of the first potentially habitable exoplanets detected by Kepler.

name: Kepler-62f
description: Kepler-62f is a super-Earth in the outer habitable zone of its star. Its size and orbit make it a candidate for potential liquid water and long-term habitability studies.

name: Mercury
description: Mercury is the smallest and innermost planet in the Solar System. Its surface experiences extreme temperature swings and has a large iron core relative to its size.

name: Venus
description: Venus is Earth's twin in size but with a thick, toxic atmosphere of CO2 and sulfuric acid clouds. It has the hottest surface temperature of any planet in the Solar System.

name: Earth
description: Earth is the only known planet to support life, with abundant liquid water, a protective atmosphere, and a magnetic field shielding the surface from solar radiation.

name: Mars
description: Mars, the Red Planet, has evidence of ancient water flows, polar ice caps, and the tallest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons.

name: Jupiter
description: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System. Its strong magnetic field, Great Red Spot, and dozens of moons make it a laboratory for studying gas giants and planetary formation.

name: Saturn
description: Saturn is famous for its spectacular ring system composed of ice and rock. Its moons, especially Titan and Enceladus, show potential for subsurface oceans and prebiotic chemistry.

name: Uranus
description: Uranus is an ice giant with a unique sideways rotation and faint ring system. Its cold atmosphere is rich in methane, giving the planet a cyan hue.

name: Neptune
description: Neptune is the outermost planet in the Solar System, known for its strong winds and storm systems. Triton, its largest moon, is geologically active and has a retrograde orbit.

name: Kepler-37b
description: Kepler-37b is a tiny rocky planet slightly larger than our Moon. Its discovery demonstrates the precision of transit detection for extremely small exoplanets.

name: Kepler-444b
description: Kepler-444b is a small, ancient terrestrial planet orbiting an 11-billion-year-old star. Its extreme age provides insight into planetary formation in the early universe.
